aws::graph::propositions: # Ryan Navion Aircraft Accident at Rocky Mountain Metropolitan Airport
A Ryan Navion aircraft with registration N4276K settled onto the runway during initial climb at Rocky Mountain Metropolitan Airport.
The accident occurred on March 15, 2013, at 1408 mountain daylight time.
The accident location was Broomfield, Colorado.
The Ryan Navion aircraft sustained substantial damage to both wings when it impacted terrain.
The pilot and three passengers were uninjured in the accident.
The aircraft was registered to the pilot.
The aircraft was operated by the pilot.
The flight was operated under 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91.
The flight was classified as a personal flight.
Visual meteorological conditions prevailed during the flight.
The flight was destined for Albuquerque International Sunport Airport.
Albuquerque International Sunport Airport is located in Albuquerque, New Mexico.
The pilot performed a "normal" run up before takeoff.
The pilot began takeoff roll on runway 29R.
Runway 29R is 9,000 feet long.
Runway 29R is 100 feet wide.
Runway 29R is made of asphalt.
The pilot described the takeoff roll as "normal".
The pilot rotated the aircraft at 60 mph as specified in the airplane flight manual.
The pilot established a best angle of climb (Vx) at 80 mph.
Upon positive rate of climb, the pilot retracted the landing gear.
The landing gear speed limitation was 100 mph.
After gear retraction, the airspeed deteriorated quickly from 80 mph to 60 mph.
The pilot reduced pitch to regain airspeed.
An excessive descent rate caused the pilot to extend the landing gear.
The pilot leveled the wings for an imminent ground impact.
The pilot made an error in the airplane weight and balance calculation.
The pilot failed to add the weight of fuel in the airplane wingtip tanks.
The aircraft had a takeoff weight of 3,208 lbs.
The maximum gross weight of the Ryan Navion aircraft was 3,100 lbs.
The aircraft was equipped with a higher horsepower engine.
The pilot stated the higher horsepower engine made the aircraft equivalent to a later model.
The later model of the aircraft had a maximum gross weight of 3,300 lbs.

text:
# Factual Information

## History of Flight

| | |
| --- | --- |
| Initial climb | Loss of lift (Defining event) |
| Uncontrolled descent | Attempted remediation/recovery |
| Landing-flare/touchdown | Loss of control on ground |
| Landing-landing roll | Collision with terr/obj (non-CFIT) |

On March 15, 2013, at 1408 mountain daylight time, a Ryan Navion, N4276K, settled onto the runway during an initial climb and subsequently veered off the runway at Rocky Mountain Metropolitan Airport, Broomfield, Colorado. The airplane sustained substantial damage to both wings when it impacted terrain. The pilot and three passengers were uninjured. The airplane was registered to and operated by the pilot under 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91 as a personal flight. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed for the flight that was destined to Albuquerque International Sunport Airport, Albuquerque, New Mexico.

The pilot stated that after a "normal" run up, he began a takeoff roll on runway 29R (9,000 feet by 100 feet, asphalt). The takeoff roll was "normal" and he rotated the airplane at 60 mph as per the airplane flight manual. He then established a best angle of climb (Vx) at 80 mph. Upon positive rate of climb, he retracted the landing gear so as not to exceed the 100 mph landing gear speed limitation. After gear retraction, the airspeed deteriorated quickly from 80 mph to 60 mph. The pilot said he immediately reduced pitch to regain airspeed. An excessive descent rate caused him to extend the landing gear and level the wings for an imminent ground impact.

The pilot stated that he made an error in the airplane weight and balance calculation by failing to add the weight of fuel in the airplane wingtip tanks, which resulted in the airplane having a takeoff weight of 3,208 lbs. The maximum gross weight of the airplane was 3,100 lbs.

The pilot stated that the airplane was equipped with a higher horsepower engine and therefore equivalent to a later model of airplane, which had a maximum gross weight of 3,300 lbs.
